doc.field: Toepfer wants to pay back compensation

The former minister of construction, Toepfer, wants to pay back 500,000 DEM to the federal government. He received the compensation for his move to a position with the UN. The CDU politician said in Bonn that this was his personal decision and that did not change the legality of this payment. Opposing this view, the parliamentary secretary-general of the SPD- faction in the Bundestag, Struck, announced that the procedure did not comply with budget regulations. The payment was intended to compensate for income losses resulting from Toepfer's new job as an executive director of the UN's environmental organization in Nairobi. The money was paid out of the budget of the Foreign Ministry. Its speaker confirmed that over the past years two high-ranking German officials had received a combined total of about one million DEM for their move to the UN.

According to the SPD chancellor candidate Gerhard Schroeder, the party platform for the elections will be the most market-economy orientated one in history. The goals were the fight against unemployment and fundamental reforms of the economy, government, and society, Schroeder said after the SPD party council passed the platform in Bonn. If the SPD won the elections, a social-democratic government would make corrections to the restrictions of sick pay decided by the current government. The paper also promised to revoke the unsocial pension reduction.
Schroeder criticises demands for Rau's resignation

SPD-Chancellor candidate Schroeder tried to end the inner-party discussion regarding the resignation of Johannes Rau, state premier of North Rhine-Westphalia. Reacting to demands made by the former chairman of the SPD state-assembly faction, Fahrtmann, Schroeder called this an improper treatment of such an esteemed person. Rau himself seemed to be unimpressed by the whole debate while taking part in the meeting of the SPD executive board. He said that he had his own schedule and that he wanted to act according to it.

According to CDU secretary-general Hintze, Chancellor Kohl continues to be the leading candidate for the elections in September. After a meeting of the party executive board, Hintze announced that faction leader Wolfgang Schaeuble would receive an outstanding position as chairman of the programme commission. Kohl also asked the minister of transportation, Wissmann, to take on the responsibility for the economic policy of the CDU during the election campaign.
Kohl should resign during the next term

Heiner Geissler, member of the CDU executive board, called upon Chancellor Kohl to resign before the end of the next term. Talking to the Sueddeutsche Zeitung, he said that Kohl had to pass his position on to party chairman Wolfgang Schaeuble. The vice president of the BDI (Federation of German Industry) had made a similar demand last weekend.
Koschnick optimistic before second mediation round

The second mediation round in the collective bargaining for Germany's public sector has started. One of the mediators, the former mayor of Bremen Hans Koschnick, said before the beginning of the talks outside the city of Baden-Baden that all parties seemed prepared to reach an agreement. The negotiations concerning about 3.2 million employees had failed earlier this month. The unions OeTV and DAG demanded an increase of 4.5%, while the employers of the state, the countries and the communities had offered 1.4%. Simultaneously they wanted concessions, e.g. in the matter of sick pay.

Once again the Federal Anti-Trust Office has imposed a high fine on a producer of high-voltage cables because of illegal price agreements. The government authority in Berlin mentioned the company "Waskoenig und Walter" by name. The company was accused of dividing up the market amon itself and 15 other cable producers for years. The other companies had already been fined a total of about 280 million DEM.
Catholic Church: no co-responsibility for Holocaust

In the Vatican's opinion, the Catholic Church bears no co-responsibility for the Nazi genocide of the Jewish population. According to a declaration of the papal commission for relations to the Jews, the unspeakable tragedy of the holocaust had its roots outside of Christianity. However, Christians would have to face the reproach that they had not done everything humanly possible to save persecuted Jews. The Catholic Church asked for forgiveness for the mistakes of its followers. Israel's high rabbi, Lau, demanded a clear apology from the Vatican for the lack of resistance against the Nazi mass murder. The declaration published today only referred to the attitude of the Catholic Church to the persecution of Jews in general. In Lau's opinion, an open condemnation could have prevented terrible events during World War II.

The police in Baden-Wuerttemberg has arrested two men suspected of toxic waste racketeering. Arrest warrants were issued against the former general manager and a stockholder of the recycling centre Elsach. The Frankurter Rundschau newspaper wrote that one of them had confessed and incriminated defendants in a toxic waste court trial in Frankfurt. It has information that in the 1990s the two managers had arranged the waste disposal of 6000 tons of contaminated waste on dumps in Saxony- Anhalt.
